core_idea: The document outlines Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees, including specific provisions related to public health emergencies like COVID-19. It details employee eligibility, accrual, permissible uses of leave, employer obligations, enforcement, and anti-retaliation protections to ensure workers can take paid sick leave for health-related and family care reasons without penalty. The key concepts include accrual rates, reasons for leave, public health emergency supplements, recordkeeping, and employer notification requirements.
initial_content:
Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.
Employee Eligibility
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.
How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.
Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:
The employee:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee needs to care for a family member who:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:
(i) The employee’s place of business; or
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.
Taking Paid Sick Leave
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.
Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.
Paid Sick Leave at Separation
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.
Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):
An employee’s need to:
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(v) Care for a family member who:
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
Or if:
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
Or to:
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;
Or due to:
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.
Recordkeeping
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.
Anti-Retaliation
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.
Notice to Employees
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.
Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.
***
Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts. If you have questions about the HFWA, including the poster and employee notice requirements, revisions to language in employee handbooks, implementation strategies, or any other workplace issues, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.

optimizations.query: new employment laws in colorado 2023 for small businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado enacted several new employment laws affecting small businesses, with key changes spanning paid leave, discrimination protections, wage transparency, and workers’ rights.

1. **Paid Leave and Sick Leave Expansions**:  
   - Starting March 10, 2023, HB 23-1045 extended leave for Colorado National Guard training from 15 days to three weeks for both public and private employees.  
   - Effective August 7, 2023, SB 23-017 broadened the uses of paid sick leave under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA). Employees can now use paid sick leave to grieve a family member’s death, attend funerals, handle related legal/financial matters, care for family members when their school or care facility closes unexpectedly (e.g., due to weather or utility loss), or evacuate their residence for similar emergencies. Employers should update sick leave policies accordingly [1][2].  
   - The HFWA requires all Colorado employers to provide paid sick leave accrued at a rate of one hour per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, with carryover allowed. Employees may use leave in one-hour increments and cannot be required to find replacements to take leave. The law also mandates job protection and prohibits retaliation for leave use [2][6].

2. **Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights Act (POWR)**:  
   - Effective August 7, 2023, POWR significantly expanded protections under the Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act. It redefined harassment, added marital status as a protected class, altered employer defenses in discrimination claims, voided certain nondisclosure agreements, and imposed new recordkeeping requirements. Small businesses should review and update personnel policies and agreements to ensure compliance [1][2].

3. **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (Effective January 1, 2024)**:  
   - SB 23-105 requires employers to post job opportunities internally and externally simultaneously, including specific compensation ranges, benefits, and application deadlines. After hiring, employers must notify employees who will work with the new hire about the selected candidate and how to express interest in similar roles. The law also mandates disclosure of career progression requirements for applicable positions. These changes aim to increase pay transparency and reduce wage discrimination [1][2].

4. **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA) (Effective July 1, 2024)**:  
   - JAFA prohibits employers from requesting age, date of birth, or education attendance/graduation dates on initial job applications. Employers may still verify age for legal compliance but cannot ask for this information upfront. Violations can result in fines enforced by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) [1][2].

5. **Workers’ Compensation Amendments**:  
   - HB 23-1076 increased the maximum medical impairment benefits for mental impairments from 12 to 36 weeks, affecting claims related to mental health conditions [1].

6. **Additional Notable Changes for Small Businesses**:  
   - The Public Employees’ Workplace Protection Act (SB 23-111) grants new labor rights to public sector employees, including protections against retaliation for workplace discussions and political participation, with phased effective dates in 2023 and 2024 [1].  
   - Employers should also prepare for upcoming changes in 2024 and beyond, including amendments to noncompete agreements, the CROWN Act expanding protections against hair discrimination, and new biometric data privacy requirements [2].

7. **Wage and Hour Enforcement Enhancements (Effective 2025)**:  
   - New laws increase penalties for wage violations, require public disclosure of willful violators, and expand the definition of “employer” to include significant owners. Employers face stricter enforcement and potential license sanctions for noncompliance [5].

In summary, small businesses in Colorado must update their policies on paid sick leave, wage transparency, discrimination protections, and hiring practices to comply with 2023-2024 laws. Staying informed and consulting legal counsel is advisable to navigate these evolving requirements effectively [1][2][5][6].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.  

### Recordkeeping  
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.  

### Anti-Retaliation  
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.  

### Notice to Employees  
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.  
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.  

### Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated  
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.

### Recent Employment Law Updates in Colorado (2023-2024)  
In addition to the HFWA, Colorado has enacted several new employment laws and amendments relevant to small businesses that impact workplace policies and compliance:  

- **2024 Amendments to the HFWA:** The HFWA has been expanded to include additional permissible reasons for leave, such as leave related to reproductive health care and organ or bone marrow donation, further broadening employee protections. Employers should review and update their paid sick leave policies accordingly.  

- **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA):** Effective in 2023, JAFA prohibits employers from asking applicants about their age or date of birth on initial job applications, aiming to reduce age discrimination in hiring. Employers should revise application forms to comply.  

- **Colorado Equal Pay for Equal Work Act (EPEWA) Amendments:** New disclosure and notice requirements have been added, including providing pay range information to applicants and employees, and posting updated notices about employee rights. Employers must update hiring and compensation practices to meet these requirements.  

- **Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Act:** Starting in 2024, Colorado’s FAMLI program provides paid family and medical leave insurance benefits to eligible employees. Employers are required to contribute to the program and provide notice to employees. Small businesses should prepare for administrative and payroll changes.  

- **Noncompete Statute Changes:** Amendments have enhanced enforcement mechanisms and increased penalties for violations of noncompete agreements, emphasizing the need for employers to carefully draft and enforce such agreements in compliance with state law.  

- **CROWN Act Amendments:** Colorado has expanded protections against discrimination based on hair texture and protective hairstyles, including prohibiting discrimination based on hair length, reinforcing inclusive workplace policies.  

- **Colorado Disability Opportunity Office (CDOO):** Established to promote employment opportunities for individuals with disabilities, the CDOO offers resources and support that employers can leverage to enhance workplace inclusion.  

- **Biometric Data Privacy Requirements:** Effective July 2025, new laws will regulate the collection, use, and storage of biometric data, requiring employers to implement policies protecting employee biometric information. Employers should begin preparing compliance strategies.  

### Practical Compliance Tips for Small Businesses  
Small businesses should:  
- Regularly review and update employee handbooks and policies to incorporate HFWA amendments and other new laws.  
- Ensure job application forms and hiring practices comply with JAFA and EPEWA requirements.  
- Prepare for FAMLI program participation by understanding contribution obligations and employee notifications.  
- Consult legal counsel to review noncompete agreements and ensure enforceability under updated statutes.  
- Update anti-discrimination policies to reflect CROWN Act protections.  
- Develop data privacy policies addressing biometric information ahead of the 2025 effective date.  

Jackson Lewis attorneys remain available to assist employers with compliance strategies, policy updates, employee handbook revisions, and navigating these evolving employment laws in Colorado. Employers are encouraged to seek legal guidance to ensure full compliance and mitigate risks.  

### Employee Handbook Templates and Guidance  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA, many resources are available for employee handbook templates that include paid sick leave policies consistent with the Act. Employers can purchase or download these templates from reputable legal and HR service providers, including Jackson Lewis, SHRM, Business-in-a-Box, Nolo’s Create Your Own Employee Handbook, HR Enterprise, and other specialized vendors. These templates typically range from basic policy outlines to comprehensive handbooks covering multiple workplace laws and regulations. Pricing models vary and may include one-time purchases or subscription-based access, depending on the provider.

For example, SHRM offers an Employee Handbook Builder through a subscription model that provides customizable templates, regular updates, and compliance alerts, helping employers tailor policies to meet HFWA requirements. When selecting or customizing an employee handbook, employers should ensure the paid sick leave provisions align with HFWA requirements, including accrual rates, permissible uses of leave, notice procedures, and anti-retaliation protections. Many templates offer customization options to tailor policies to company-specific practices, workforce languages, and operational needs. optimizations.query: new employee legal requirements in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado implemented several key legal requirements for new employees that employers must follow:

1. **Equal Pay and Job Posting Requirements (SB 23-105, effective January 1, 2024):** Employers must post job opportunities both internally and externally on the same day, including specific compensation information (hourly rate or salary range), a general description of benefits, and the anticipated application window closing date. The law excludes "career development" or "career progression" changes from internal posting requirements but requires disclosure of career progression terms to eligible employees. After hiring, employers must notify employees who work closely with the new hire about the selected candidate’s name, former and new job titles, and how to express interest in similar future jobs. Employers with no physical presence in Colorado and fewer than 15 remote employees in the state have limited posting obligations until July 1, 2029. The Colorado Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces these rules and will mediate wage complaints starting July 1, 2024, with back pay recoverable up to six years for wage discrimination claims [1][2].

2. **Paid Sick Leave Expansion (SB 23-017, effective August 7, 2023):** Under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually. The law expanded allowable reasons for using paid sick leave to include grieving or attending funerals for family members, handling related legal or financial matters, caring for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or other unexpected events, and evacuating residences under similar conditions. Employers cannot retaliate against employees for taking such leave and cannot require a doctor’s note until after four consecutive missed shifts [1][2][4][6].

3. **Prohibition on Age-Related Questions in Job Applications (SB 23-058, effective July 1, 2024):** Employers are prohibited from asking applicants to disclose age, date of birth, or dates of attendance/graduation on initial job applications. Exceptions exist for bona fide occupational qualifications or legal requirements. Violations may result in fines enforced by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) [1][2][4].

4. **Anti-Discrimination and Harassment Law Updates (POWR Act, SB 23-172, effective August 7, 2023):** The law broadens protections against workplace discrimination and harassment, including redefining harassment standards and adding marital status as a protected class. It restricts nondisclosure agreements related to discriminatory practices and requires employers to maintain a repository of all discrimination or harassment complaints, which may be used in litigation. Employers should update policies and recordkeeping accordingly [1][2][4].

5. **Other Notable 2023 Changes:**
   - Minimum wage increased to $13.65/hour statewide (higher in Denver) as of January 1, 2023 [3].
   - Expanded leave for Colorado National Guard training (HB 23-1045) allowing three weeks of leave annually [2].
   - Public employees gained new workplace rights under the Public Employees’ Workplace Protection Act (SB 23-111) [2].
   - Amendments to workers’ compensation and noncompete laws also took effect [2][4].

Employers in Colorado should review and update their hiring, job posting, leave, anti-discrimination, and recordkeeping policies to ensure compliance with these 2023 legal requirements and prepare for additional changes effective in 2024 [1][2][3][4].

In summary, SHRM’s paid sick leave policy resources offer HR professionals expert guidance and customizable templates to develop compliant, clear, and effective sick leave policies that balance employee needs and operational requirements [1][2][4][6]. For full access to SHRM’s policy templates and detailed guidance, membership is typically required.

optimizations.query: what are the new worker benefits requirements in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado introduced several new worker benefits requirements affecting both public and private sector employees, with key changes including expanded leave rights, paid sick leave uses, workplace protections, and discrimination law updates:

1. **Employee Leave for Colorado National Guard Training (Effective March 10, 2023):**  
Employees in both public and private sectors are entitled to a three-week leave of absence per calendar year for certain military service and training, an increase from the previous 15 days. Employees may use paid or unpaid leave for this absence. The law also removes the prior restriction that public employees must not be mentally or physically disabled to be reinstated after leave [1].

2. **Expanded Uses for Paid Sick Leave (Effective August 7, 2023):**  
Under SB 23-017, employees may now use paid sick leave to grieve or attend funerals for family members, handle legal or financial matters after a family member’s death, care for family members whose school or care facility closes unexpectedly (due to weather, power loss, etc.), and evacuate their residence under similar emergency conditions. Employers should update sick leave policies accordingly [1][2].

3. **Public Employees’ Workplace Protection Act (Effective August 7, 2023, with some provisions effective July 1, 2024):**  
This act grants public employees rights similar to private sector workers, including the right to discuss workplace issues, join employee organizations, and participate politically while off duty. It prohibits retaliation by public employers against employees exercising these rights and is enforced by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment [1].

4. **Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights Act (POWR) (Effective August 7, 2023):**  
POWR expands the Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act by redefining harassment, adding marital status as a protected class, modifying employer defenses in discrimination claims, voiding certain nondisclosure agreements, and imposing new recordkeeping requirements. Employers should revise policies and agreements to comply [1][2].

5. **Workers’ Compensation Amendments (Effective 2023):**  
The limit on medical impairment benefits for mental impairment increased from 12 weeks to 36 weeks [1].

6. **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (Effective January 1, 2024):**  
Employers must post job opportunities internally and externally with specific compensation and benefits information, announce selected candidates to coworkers, and disclose career progression requirements. The statute of limitations for wage discrimination claims extends from three to six years. The law is enforced by the State Division of Labor Standards and Statistics [1][2][3].

7. **Job Application Fairness Act (Effective July 1, 2024):**  
Employers are prohibited from requesting age-related information (age, date of birth, education dates) on initial job applications to reduce age discrimination. Violations can result in fines enforced by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment [1][2][3].

8. **Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Act (Effective January 1, 2024):**  
Colorado workers gain access to up to 12 weeks of paid leave (plus 4 additional weeks for pregnancy/childbirth complications) for bonding with a new child, serious health conditions, family caregiving, military deployment arrangements, or domestic violence impacts. Both employers and employees contribute premiums. Job protection is guaranteed after six months of employment [2][3].

9. **Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) Updates:**  
Employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually. Leave can be used for personal or family illness, preventive care, domestic violence recovery, and public health emergencies. Employers cannot retaliate against employees for taking leave or require a doctor’s note until after four consecutive missed shifts [2][6].

10. **Additional Compliance and Benefits Requirements:**  
Employers must comply with Affordable Care Act (ACA) mandates if applicable, including offering minimum essential coverage and filing required forms. Health Savings Account (HSA) contribution limits and Qualified Small Employer Health Reimbursement Arrangements (QSEHRA) rules apply. Employers should update plan documents and notify employees of benefits changes to avoid penalties [5].

In summary, Colorado’s 2023 worker benefits requirements emphasize expanded paid leave rights, enhanced workplace protections, pay transparency, anti-discrimination enforcement, and new paid family leave benefits, with several provisions phased in through 2024. Employers should review and update policies, job postings, and benefits administration to ensure compliance and support employee well-being [1][2][3][5][6].

(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.

(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or

(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or

optimizations.query: current state laws on mandatory sick leave for businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
As of early 2026, mandatory paid sick leave laws exist in 15 U.S. states plus Washington, D.C., with additional states requiring paid leave for any reason. There is no federal paid sick leave mandate for private employers, so state laws vary significantly in coverage, accrual, usage, and qualifying reasons [1].

Key points on state mandatory sick leave laws include:

- **States with mandatory paid sick leave laws:** Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington, and Washington, D.C. These laws generally require employers to provide paid sick leave accrued based on hours worked, with typical accrual rates around 1 hour per 30 hours worked and annual maximums ranging from 40 to 48 hours [1].

- **States with mandatory paid leave for any reason:** Illinois, Maine, and Nevada require paid leave that can be used for any purpose, not just illness [1].

- **Accrual and usage:** Most states require employees to accrue paid sick leave from the start of employment and allow usage for personal illness, caring for family members (with broad definitions of family), and other reasons such as domestic violence recovery or public health emergencies. For example, Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act mandates up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, accrued at 1 hour per 30 hours worked, usable for personal or family illness, domestic violence recovery, or public health emergency-related absences [1][6].

- **Employer size thresholds:** Some states apply paid sick leave laws only to employers above certain size thresholds, which may be decreasing over time. For instance, Connecticut’s law currently applies to employers with 25 or more employees but will expand to cover all employers by 2027 [1].

- **Recent expansions and changes:** California expanded leave protections effective January 1, 2026, including leave for victims of violence and expanded family definitions for paid family and medical leave. However, this expansion does not mandate additional paid leave but allows use of accrued paid sick leave or PTO for these purposes [5].

- **Usage increments and notice:** States typically require leave to be taken in increments (often one hour), with some flexibility. Employers may set reasonable notice policies but cannot deny leave for failure to comply with such policies if the leave is otherwise valid [6].

In summary, while no federal mandate exists, a growing number of states require private employers to provide paid sick leave with varying rules on accrual, usage, and covered reasons. Employers operating in multiple states must carefully track and comply with each jurisdiction’s specific requirements to avoid penalties [1][5][6].

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.

Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.

The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.

(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

optimizations.query: current trends in worker benefits 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, worker benefits trends reflect a strong focus on holistic employee well-being, flexibility, and cost management amid ongoing economic and social challenges. Key trends include:

1. **Holistic Well-being and Mental Health Support**: Employers are increasingly prioritizing mental health benefits and stress management, recognizing the cumulative impact of workplace and personal stressors on employees. This includes expanding Employee Assistance Programs (EAPs), offering online mental health resources, and training managers to recognize and address behavioral health issues to prevent burnout and turnover [2][4][5].

2. **Flexible Work Arrangements**: Remote and hybrid work options remain highly valued, with 87% of workers preferring flexible schedules when available. Employers are also extending flexibility to non-remote roles through adaptable schedules, job sharing, and activity-based workspaces to support work-life balance and improve employee satisfaction [4][5].

3. **Cost-Effective Healthcare Strategies**: Managing rising healthcare costs is critical. Employers are adopting strategies such as telemedicine, modifying health plan designs, improving healthcare literacy, and incentivizing cost-effective care to keep benefits affordable while maintaining quality [4][2].

4. **Voluntary and Family-Friendly Benefits**: There is growing interest in voluntary benefits like critical illness, accident, pet insurance, and student loan repayment assistance, allowing employees to customize their benefits. Family-friendly benefits, including paid parental leave, adoption support, and reproductive health services, are also expanding to meet diverse employee needs [4][5].

5. **Pay Transparency and Financial Education**: Transparency in pay is becoming more important for attracting talent, with some employers publishing pay scales. Financial education programs are also gaining traction to help employees manage economic pressures and reduce financial stress [4][5].

6. **Inclusive Leave Policies and Paid Sick Leave**: Enhanced leave policies, including paid family caregiver leave and sick leave, are being implemented. For example, Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act mandates paid sick leave accrual and usage for various health and family care reasons, reflecting a broader trend toward supporting employees’ health and caregiving responsibilities [6][4].

7. **Focus on Employee Experience and Culture**: Employers are investing in workplace culture and employee engagement to retain talent, emphasizing transparency, communication, and recognition as part of the benefits ecosystem [5][2].

Overall, 2023 benefits trends emphasize a comprehensive approach that supports employees’ mental, physical, and financial well-being, while balancing cost and flexibility to attract and retain talent in a competitive labor market [2][4][5].

References:  
[2] 2023 NFP US Benefits Trend Report  
[4] NIS Benefits Blog: Employee Benefit Trends for 2023  
[5] ESOP Partners: Top 9 Employee Benefit Trends for 2023

The new sick leave requirements for businesses in Colorado are governed by the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates that all employers, regardless of size, provide paid sick leave to their employees starting January 1, 2022. Employees accrue one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours (6 days) per year, with unused leave carrying over to the next year but usage capped at 48 hours annually. Employers may also frontload the full 48 hours at the start of the year if they choose [3][4][6].

Employees can use accrued sick leave for a broad range of reasons including their own physical or mental illness, injury, medical appointments, preventive care, and to care for family members with similar health needs. Covered family members include children (biological, adopted, foster, or stepchildren), spouses or domestic partners, parents, grandparents, grandchildren, and siblings. Additionally, sick leave can be used for issues related to domestic violence, sexual assault, or harassment, such as seeking medical attention, counseling, legal services, or relocation [3][4][6].

The HFWA also includes provisions for Public Health Emergency (PHE) leave, which grants employees up to 80 hours of supplemental paid sick leave during declared public health emergencies (pro-rated for part-time workers). This leave covers reasons such as self-isolation, medical care related to the emergency, caring for family members affected, or when schools or childcare facilities are closed due to the emergency. Employers must supplement accrued leave to ensure this amount is available and cannot require documentation for PHE leave. This supplemental leave remains available for up to four weeks after the emergency ends [3][4][6].

Employers are required to notify employees of their rights under HFWA, maintain records of hours worked and leave used for at least two years, and are prohibited from retaliating against employees for using sick leave. Sick leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments. Employers cannot require employees to find replacement workers as a condition for taking leave. Requests for leave can be made orally, in writing, or electronically, and employers may adopt reasonable notice policies but cannot deny leave for noncompliance with such policies [3][6].

Unused sick leave is not required to be paid out upon separation unless the employer’s policy provides for it, but if an employee is rehired within six months, their unused accrued leave must be reinstated. The law exempts federal employees and independent contractors from coverage [3][6].

In summary, Colorado’s sick leave law is comprehensive, covering nearly all employees and providing protections for a wide range of health and safety-related needs, including mental health and domestic violence issues, with additional leave during public health emergencies. Employers must comply with accrual, usage, notification, and recordkeeping requirements to avoid penalties [3][4][6].

For more detailed guidance, employers and employees can consult the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics [1][3][4][6].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.

Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.

The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.

Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.  
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.  

### Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated  
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.

### Recent Employment Law Updates in Colorado (2023-2024)  
In addition to the HFWA, Colorado has enacted several new employment laws and amendments relevant to small businesses that impact workplace policies and compliance:  

- **2024 Amendments to the HFWA:** The HFWA has been expanded to include additional permissible reasons for leave, such as leave related to reproductive health care and organ or bone marrow donation, further broadening employee protections. Employers should review and update their paid sick leave policies accordingly.  

- **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA):** Effective in 2023, JAFA prohibits employers from asking applicants about their age or date of birth on initial job applications, aiming to reduce age discrimination in hiring. Employers should revise application forms to comply.  

- **Colorado Equal Pay for Equal Work Act (EPEWA) Amendments:** New disclosure and notice requirements have been added, including providing pay range information to applicants and employees, and posting updated notices about employee rights. Employers must update hiring and compensation practices to meet these requirements.  

- **Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Act:** Starting in 2024, Colorado’s FAMLI program provides paid family and medical leave insurance benefits to eligible employees. Employers are required to contribute to the program and provide notice to employees. Small businesses should prepare for administrative and payroll changes.  

- **Noncompete Statute Changes:** Amendments have enhanced enforcement mechanisms and increased penalties for violations of noncompete agreements, emphasizing the need for employers to carefully draft and enforce such agreements in compliance with state law.  

- **CROWN Act Amendments:** Colorado has expanded protections against discrimination based on hair texture and protective hairstyles, including prohibiting discrimination based on hair length, reinforcing inclusive workplace policies.  

- **Colorado Disability Opportunity Office (CDOO):** Established to promote employment opportunities for individuals with disabilities, the CDOO offers resources and support that employers can leverage to enhance workplace inclusion.  

- **Biometric Data Privacy Requirements:** Effective July 2025, new laws will regulate the collection, use, and storage of biometric data, requiring employers to implement policies protecting employee biometric information. Employers should begin preparing compliance strategies.  

### Practical Compliance Tips for Small Businesses  
Small businesses should:  
- Regularly review and update employee handbooks and policies to incorporate HFWA amendments and other new laws.  
- Ensure job application forms and hiring practices comply with JAFA and EPEWA requirements.  
- Prepare for FAMLI program participation by understanding contribution obligations and employee notifications.  
- Consult legal counsel to review noncompete agreements and ensure enforceability under updated statutes.  
- Update anti-discrimination policies to reflect CROWN Act protections.  
- Develop data privacy policies addressing biometric information ahead of the 2025 effective date.  

Jackson Lewis attorneys remain available to assist employers with compliance strategies, policy updates, employee handbook revisions, and navigating these evolving employment laws in Colorado. Employers are encouraged to seek legal guidance to ensure full compliance and mitigate risks.  

### Employee Handbook Templates and Guidance  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA, many resources are available for employee handbook templates that include paid sick leave policies consistent with the Act. Employers can purchase or download these templates from reputable legal and HR service providers, including Jackson Lewis, SHRM, Business-in-a-Box, Nolo’s Create Your Own Employee Handbook, HR Enterprise, and other specialized vendors. These templates typically range from basic policy outlines to comprehensive handbooks covering multiple workplace laws and regulations. Pricing models vary and may include one-time purchases or subscription-based access, depending on the provider.

For example, SHRM offers an Employee Handbook Builder through a subscription model that provides customizable templates, regular updates, and compliance alerts, helping employers tailor policies to meet HFWA requirements. Business-in-a-Box provides an extensive library of over 1,800 business and legal templates, including employee handbooks, available for a one-time purchase or subscription, with options to customize content to reflect HFWA provisions. HR Enterprise offers a customizable employee handbook template with pricing based on the number of employees, designed to help employers maintain compliance with state laws such as the HFWA.

When selecting or customizing an employee handbook, employers should ensure the paid sick leave provisions align with HFWA requirements, including accrual rates, permissible uses of leave, notice procedures, and anti-retaliation protections. Many templates offer customization options to tailor policies to company-specific practices, workforce languages, and operational needs. It is important that employers carefully review and update handbook language regularly to incorporate any changes to the HFWA or related regulations, ensuring ongoing compliance.

Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts, including revisions to language in employee handbooks, implementation strategies, and other workplace issues. If you have questions about the HFWA, including the poster and employee notice requirements, or need guidance on selecting, customizing, or purchasing employee handbook templates, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.

Employers seeking to manage compliance with Colorado’s paid sick leave laws, including the HFWA, can benefit from specialized leave management software designed to automate tracking, accrual, usage, and reporting of paid sick leave. Leading software solutions such as AbsenceSoft, Paychex, and others offer platforms that integrate Colorado-specific paid sick leave rules, including accrual rates, permissible leave reasons, and carryover limits. These tools help employers streamline leave requests, maintain accurate records, generate compliance reports, and reduce administrative burden.

Key features to consider include automated accrual calculations, employee self-service portals, integration with payroll systems, alerts for policy updates, and support for multi-state compliance. Utilizing such software can enhance accuracy, ensure timely compliance with HFWA requirements, and mitigate risks of violations or penalties. Employers are encouraged to evaluate software options based on their company size, industry, and specific compliance needs, and to consult legal counsel for guidance on integrating technology solutions with their overall compliance strategy.

### Colorado Secretary of State’s Role in Business Compliance  
In addition to employment law compliance, Colorado employers should be aware of the Colorado Secretary of State’s office, which plays a critical role in business legislation and compliance. The Secretary of State oversees business registration, filing requirements, periodic reports, trade name filings, and other essential business compliance functions. Employers must ensure timely filings and maintain good standing by submitting required annual or periodic reports and updating business information as necessary.

The business registration process includes filing formation documents for entities such as corporations, limited liability companies (LLCs), and partnerships through the Secretary of State’s online portal. Employers should integrate Secretary of State compliance with their employment law obligations, such as the HFWA, to ensure comprehensive legal adherence.
